hints.Welding safety: Essential precautions and guidelines for protecting welders from potential hazards such as heat, fumes, and electricity.
hints.Oxyfuel cutting (OFC): A cutting process that uses a combination of fuel gases and oxygen to cut metals.
hints.Shielded Metal Arc Welding (SMAW): A manual arc welding process that uses a consumable electrode coated with a flux to lay the weld.
hints.Gas Metal Arc Welding (GMAW): Also known as MIG welding, this process uses a continuous wire feed as an electrode and an inert shielding gas to protect the weld from contamination.
hints.Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW): Also called TIG welding, this process uses a non-consumable tungsten electrode and an inert shielding gas to create high-quality welds.
hints.Plasma Arc Cutting (PAC): A cutting process that uses an electrically conductive gas (plasma) to transfer energy from an electrical power source to the workpiece.
hints.Flux-Cored Arc Welding (FCAW): A variation of GMAW that uses a tubular wire filled with flux, providing additional shielding and eliminating the need for an external gas supply.
hints.Welding joints: Different types of connections between workpieces, such as butt, lap, corner, edge, and tee joints.
hints.Welding positions: The orientation of the welder and workpiece during welding, including flat, horizontal, vertical, and overhead positions.
hints.Welding symbols: Standardized symbols used on blueprints to communicate welding requirements, such as type, size, and location of welds.
hints.Welding techniques: Various methods used to manipulate the welding process, such as weaving, stringer beads, and whip motion.
hints.Welding metallurgy: The study of how metals react to heat and pressure during welding, including the effects on material properties, structure, and performance.
hints.Electrodes and filler metals: Materials used in welding processes to join workpieces, available in various types and sizes based on application requirements.
hints.Welding equipment maintenance: Proper care and maintenance of welding equipment to ensure safe operation, longevity, and optimal performance.
hints.Welding inspection and quality control: Methods for assessing the quality of welds, including visual inspection, destructive testing, and non-destructive testing techniques.
